title: NCBA Bank Tanzania
text:
NCBA Bank Tanzania Limited, is a merged bank between <a href="Commercial%20Bank%20of%20Africa%20%28Tanzania%29">Commercial Bank of Africa (Tanzania)</a> and NIC Bank Tanzania. It is a <a href="commercial%20bank">commercial bank</a> in <a href="Tanzania">Tanzania</a> licensed by the <a href="Bank%20of%20Tanzania">Bank of Tanzania</a>, the <a href="central%20bank">central bank</a> and national banking regulator.
Location.
The headquarters of the bank are located on the 1st, 2nd and 10th Floor, at Amani Place Building, along Ohio Street, in the <a href="central%20business%20district">central business district</a> of <a href="Dar%20es%20Salaam">Dar es Salaam</a>, Tanzania's financial capital. The geographical coordinates of the bank's headquarters are:06°48'41.5"S, 39°17'15.0"E (Latitude:-6.811528; Longitude:39.287500).
Overview.
NCBA Bank Tanzania is a medium-sized financial services provider in Tanzania. Its total assets as of 31 March 2020 was approximately TZS:508 billion (US$210 million), with TZS:61.2 billion (US$26.5 million), in shareholders equity. At that time, it was categorized as a "Tier II Commercial Bank" in Tanzania. The bank is a subsidiary of <a href="NCBA%20Group%20Plc">NCBA Group Plc</a>, a financial services conglomerate with headquarters in Kenya and subsidiaries in <a href="Kenya">Kenya</a>, <a href="Rwanda">Rwanda</a>, Tanzania, <a href="Uganda">Uganda</a> and <a href="Ivory%20Coast">Ivory Coast</a>.
History.
NIC Bank Tanzania started as a <a href="non-bank%20financial%20institution">non-bank financial institution</a> in 1994. In 2004, following the issuance of a banking license by the Bank of Tanzania, the institution converted into a fully fledged commercial bank, under the SFCB name. In May 2009, NIC Bank, a large financial services provider based in <a href="Nairobi">Nairobi</a> and traded on the <a href="Nairobi%20Stock%20Exchange">Nairobi Stock Exchange</a>, took a 51 percent shareholding position in SFCB. During 2010, the Tanzanian subsidiary successfully re-branded to NIC Bank Tanzania.
Commercial Bank of Africa was founded in 1962 in <a href="Dar%20es%20Salaam">Dar es Salaam</a>. Branches were soon opened in Nairobi and <a href="Mombasa">Mombasa</a>, Kenya and in <a href="Kampala%2C%20Uganda">Kampala, Uganda</a>. When Tanzania nationalized private banks in 1967, the bank moved its headquarters to Nairobi. Following political changes in Uganda in 1971, the bank sold its assets in that country. In July 2005, the Commercial Bank of Africa (CBA) acquired majority shareholding in First American Bank of Kenya, which at the time had a <a href="Tanzania">Tanzania</a>n subsidiary called United Bank of Africa.
NCBA Group.
In September 2019, <a href="NIC%20Bank%20Group">NIC Bank Group</a> received regulatory approval from the <a href="Central%20Bank%20of%20Kenya">Central Bank of Kenya</a>, to merge with <a href="Commercial%20Bank%20of%20Africa">Commercial Bank of Africa</a>, forming the <a href="NCBA%20Group%20Plc">NCBA Group Plc</a>, effective 1 October 2019.
In July 2020, having secured approval of the relevant banking regulators in Tanzania, NIC Bank Tanzania and Commercial Bank of Africa (Tanzania) merged to form NCBA Bank Tanzania.
Ownership.
As of September 2020, NCBA Bank Tanzania is a subsidiary and member of the NCBA Bank Group (<a href="NCBA%20Group%20Plc">NCBA Group Plc</a>, whose shares of <a href="stock">stock</a> trade on the <a href="Nairobi%20Securities%20Exchange">Nairobi Securities Exchange</a> under the symbol: NCBA.
